courseDescription:
Are you looking to develop an insight into how the recruitment industry functions? Or are you looking to make a long-term investment in your organisation's future with an improvement in its recruitment policy? This course on the fundamentals of the recruitment industry will provide a history of how the industry has evolved. In addition, we explain the critical legislation to comply with if you're a recruitment agency in the UK.

Are you looking for techniques to improve your recruitment agency's outreach through better marketing? The course will equip you with advice to help improve sales and marketing for recruitment agencies. We shall also carry out an identification of the pivotal stages of the recruitment process. Key performance indicators (KPI) are crucial for every organisation. We demonstrate how to develop effective KPIs for long-term success and outline how to acquire and manage clients and candidates so you can establish a sound client base.

The final section deals with the candidate interview procedure and will help you make this as efficient as possible. We guide you through the preparation and execution process for an effective interview and candidate screening. The course will also guide budding entrepreneurs in ensuring they are fully aware of the challenges of starting their own recruitment agency. Whether an employer or employee, the recruitment sector is crucial to any organisation.

  • Lesson Summary
  • Below you will find key information covered in this module:    
    • Recruitment is the process of attracting, screening, and selecting qualified people for a role at an organization.
    • Employees are one of the most crucial factors in any organization, hence hiring the best people is essential.
    • The reason for the continued growth of recruitment agencies is their ability to quickly adapt to change and take advantage of their unique position in times of economic uncertainty.
    • Service providers typically supply both temporary and permanent staffing solutions to a company as this allows for multiple solutions for filling a vacancy.
    • Holding a recruiter's license is not a necessity for the majority of employment agencies, but it is important to be aware that there are areas where one is required.
    •  All recruitment agencies must comply with the regulations set out in the employment agencies act 1973 and conduct employment agencies and employment business regulations 2003.
    • There are 8,000 recruitment agencies in the UK, so ensuring clients can distinguish your services is essential for success.
    • The five best practices of hiring are Recruitment planning, strategy development, searching, screening, and evaluation.
    • A recruitment cycle is a clear framework consisting of four key activities and is used to reach a decision in the recruitment process.

  • Lesson Summary
  • Below you will find key information covered in this module:    
    • Candidate attraction is defined as the method used to attract candidates for a working position. The best method for attracting candidates depends on how specific the role is or the volume of candidates required.
    • The best way to structure candidate acquisition is to follow the examples set out by the AIDA - attention, interest, desire, and action.
    • Candidate management is crucial when it comes to building your brand and the way an agency treats its candidates can help grow or damage your business. 
    • When qualifying candidates, there are two types you will want to consider - REQ and SPEQ candidates.
    • It is crucial to design the interview process with the rest of the recruitment process as this allows all candidate behaviors and capabilities to be assessed.
    • It is crucial for recruitment agencies to regularly assess the customer landscape and be aware of trends and shortcomings.
    • When making an initial approach to a client, you can take a candidate-led approach or a service-led approach.
    • The most crucial part of the client strategy process should always be the act of identifying the objectives that guide your strategy.
    • Most candidates fall between two categories - active or passive.
